title: T-Money Card
content: Essential for using public transport (subways, buses). You can buy and top up T-Money at convenience stores (GS25, CU, 7-Eleven) and at subway stations.

title: Naver Map & Kakao Map
content: Naver Map and Kakao Map are widely used in Korea and often provide more accurate local and public-transport info than Google Maps—install one or both before your trip.

title: Tipping is not required
content: In Korea, tipping is not a common practice. Restaurants, cafes, and taxis do not expect tips since service charges are included in prices. You can simply pay the bill without adding extra.

title: Public Wi-Fi
content: Free Wi-Fi is commonly available in subways, buses, major tourist areas, and many cafes. Security varies, so avoid sensitive payments on public networks.

title: Removing Shoes Indoors
content: In Korea, shoes are removed in certain indoor places such as private homes, some traditional restaurants with floor seating, guesthouses, and jjimjilbang (Korean spas). However, in most modern restaurants, cafes, hotels, and shops, you keep your shoes on.

title: Papago Translator
content: Naver Papago offers text, image, and voice translation (and offline functionality). It's very useful when you need quick Korean↔English help.

title: Tax Refund
content: Foreign visitors can get VAT refunds for qualifying purchases. Minimum amounts and procedures vary—look for 'tax-free' signs, keep receipts, and claim refunds at stores, downtown refund booths, or airports.

title: Emergency Numbers
content: For emergencies call 112 (police) or 119 (fire/ambulance). For traveler assistance, call 1330.
